title: German Rocks Recipe
description: A heavy cookie with dates and nuts. Derived from Bavarian Inn, Frankenmuth, Michigan.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European German German Rocks 4.7 (14) 13 Reviews 4 Photos A heavy cookie with dates and nuts. Derived from Bavarian Inn, Frankenmuth, Michigan. Submitted by Mel Updated on July 14, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 4 4 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Total Time: 25 mins Servings: 36 Yield: 3 dozen Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 36 servings 1 ½ cups white sugar ½ cup butter 3 eggs 2 ½ cups sifted all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon hot water 2 cups dates, pitted and chopped 3 cups chopped walnuts Directions Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). In a medium bowl, cream the butter and sugar. Add eggs, one at a time, beating after each. Dissolve the baking soda in the hot water, add it to the egg mixture. Stir in the flour and cinnamon until well blended. Finally, stir in the dates and walnuts so they are evenly distributed. Drop by heaping spoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 10 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until golden. I Made It Print Nutrition Facts (per serving) 179 Calories 9g Fat 23g Carbs 3g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 36 Calories 179 % Daily Value * Total Fat 9g 12% Saturated Fat 2g 12% Cholesterol 22mg 7% Sodium 60mg 3% Total Carbohydrate 23g 8% Dietary Fiber 2g 6% Total Sugars 14g Protein 3g 6% Vitamin C 0mg 0% Calcium 18mg 1% Iron 1mg 5% Potassium 113mg 2% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Add Your Photo Photos of German Rocks 01 of 04 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 04 Photo by  Heidi S Grist 12/24/2019 Very nice cookie. Soft and not too sweet. I was hoping for a denser cookie but these are very tasty. I did decrease the nuts to one cup. Really couldn’t see putting 3 cups in. 03 of 04 Photo by  SentimentalGent 12/03/2018 I've been making a very similar recipe that my Mom would make every Christmas. I had been searching to find where the recipe came from and this seems to be it. In Pennsylvania, we call them Michigan Rocks. Now I know where the name comes from. The only variation is that I add raisins to match the amount of dates. I know a few people who add whiskey. One tip: Put cold cookies in the microwave (about 10 seconds or so for one cookie, 15 seconds or so for two, etc.). You'll think they just came out of the over. Fruit is so warm. 1 You’ll Also Love Cherry Chocolate Chunk Cookies 76 Ratings Homestead Harvest Cookies Zucchini Nut Bars 13 Ratings Holiday Lebkuchen (German Spice Cookies) 4 Ratings Aunt Bert's Fruitcake Cookies 5 Ratings State Fair Ribbon Fudge Brownies 3 Ratings Ollie Bean's Coconut Bar Cookies 2 Ratings Chocolate Lebkuchen 13 Ratings Cocoa Panforte Applesauce Cookies 78 Ratings Pfeffernusse 31 Ratings Autumn Harvest Cookies 69 Ratings Italian Chocolate Chip Cookies 14 Ratings Squash Cookies 99 Ratings Pfeffernusse III 18 Ratings Sardinian Papassini Cookies Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Mel
instructions: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).;In a medium bowl, cream the butter and sugar. Add eggs, one at a time, beating after each. Dissolve the baking soda in the hot water, add it to the egg mixture. Stir in the flour and cinnamon until well blended. Finally, stir in the dates and walnuts so they are evenly distributed.;Drop by heaping spoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet. Bake for 10 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until golden.
